Q24: I understand why we have our meetings and they're important, but I also find them to be very unengaging for me personally. I wish there was a different way to accomplish our communication goals.

Q16: Hybrid: I work from home some days out of the week, and in person others
Q89_3: Proctored technical assessment (i.e., timed, while someone watches)
Q89_7: Unproctored technical assessment (i.e., timed, with no one watching)
qual strengths:
I excel at "very boring data labeling" that most people don't have the patience/discipline for; I put on an audiobook and can spend several hours doing easy (split second) data labeling or other very light cognitive tasks. I have been told I have a far better ability to focus and not get bored.

I have also realized I excel at context-switching (for anything that doesn't require interacting with a human); I rarely "lose time" to "get back to where I was." I don't know why I am this way, I thought everyone was.

If a problem interests me, I have the drive/discipline/anxiety to work non-stop on it for 80 hours a week for weeks (then I burn out and start making mistakes). I have also come to learn this is not normal, apparently.

I am extremely good at debugging, apparently. I think it is my ability to focus that helps.

I have also learned that I am apparently a "superprogrammer" that can work 4x as fast as my peers. I think it is because I simply refuse to take breaks and/or have the discipline to stay focused.

TLDR I apparently have an unusual ability to be able to maintain focus for a very long time, even for very boring tasks.

Q23: I feel like this job is one of the few that tends to reward efficiency, had a culture of "we don't care how you do it as long as you get it done [well]" (for example no one cares what I wear to work), and it's creative, rewarding work. Therefore, this job is extremely suited to people with my kind of neurodivergence due to the autonomy and lack of behavioral expectations.
Q24: I wish people would understand that being extremely introverted I have a very small social battery and so many meetings could be emails; I hate pretty much all meetings because I find them a complete waste of time because either people talk to hear themselves talk or there is only a one-directional flow of information (so this meeting could/should have been an email...)

Q23: I think if I was not able to set working hours that work for me, then it would be very challenging to be neurodivergent. Sometimes I need to sleep more because I can't sleep at night, and subsequently need to arrive to the office later. Past jobs I had have had much stricter hours, and I felt this had an extreme mental drain on me. It can be somewhat intrusive to other aspects of my life when I mismanage my time, but I feel I am capable of providing higher quality work when I am given this freedom.
Q24: I wish I were paid more lol but I feel like my job suits me pretty well. When I burnout, it is due to me mismanaing my lifestyle and my workplace provides benefits that indirectly help me mediate these issues

Q78: Hybrid: partially working out-of-office, and some in-office
qual strengths:
Project management, brainstorming, low-level programming and debugging. 

Why do I think I enjoy them? That's either a very deep or a very simple question. Let's say: "because I subjectively perceive more satisfaction when undertaking them than when undertaking other related tasks (such as writing documentation)".

Why do I think I am good at them? I have had the opportunity to observe myself and others carry out those tasks multiple times over decades, and I can compare the outcomes when I take those roles to the outcomes when others take those roles. The answer to this also depends on the group to which one is comparing. I may not be any better at project management than other project managers at my level of seniority, but I mostly interact with more junior colleagues; compared to them, I excel at these tasks.

Q78: Hybrid: partially working out-of-office, and some in-office
qual strengths:
I haven't even been working a year....but in the past I've really enjoyed being given one complex problem to chew on for a long time as opposed to being expected to complete tasks of average difficulty at a regular pace. I think this is due to my superiority complex and attention to detail. The attention to detail comes just from my personality and anxiety, and the superiority complex comes from my mother giving me a much better math education than what was offered in most American schools. Learning some discrete math basics in middle school and being such a hater that I was obsessed with proving myself right were skills that translated VERY well to computer science. Also, after seeing all the grandstanding men in my program get everything wrong, I became convinced that if those fools somehow passed whatever class, so too would I. And I was right <3

Anyway, my approach to programming is very detailed but it takes a long time. So I enjoy more difficult but longer tasks.
cowork reason _7_TEXT: we were friends. lol

Q4: I am professionally diagnosed with ADHD
Q16: In person: I work in person the majority of the time
qual strengths:
I really enjoy having a specific task set out, with specific goals where I have free reign to accomplish them anyway I wish. I think I enjoy this because it's easy to "get a good grade in coding", and I have a definite completion goal without having someone sit over my shoulder. I also enjoy when I have someone to talk to in the office because it allows me to speak some thoughts aloud and makes it easier to keep on track with my work.

I also enjoy getting to have free reign over my current work. As a Ph.D. student, getting to specify a research question, investigate it, and find solutions under my own power is very fun.

Q78: Hybrid: partially working out-of-office, and some in-office
qual strengths:
(re)writing & reviewing code:
The rigid nature of code makes it easy for me to account for every edge case & circumstance, and once those are accounted for I see both the forest and the trees at the same time. Then, I can both write extraordinarily robust/performant/maintainable code and give extraordinarily useful reviews.


designing & implementing larger patterns/systems:
The purely-high-level nature of this exercise lets me focus solely on how the software interacts with the devs & users, and lets me focus on that balance. I combine all my knowledge of each to find the middleground that all three need in the given circumstance.


designing & implementing accessible UI/UX:
UI/UX is how the devs/company communicate with the user in realtime, using pre-programmed behaviors. I get to explore the endless landscape of communication to find ways to effectively get users to understand what we want the app to tell them, and to understand what they're doing.
As an Autistic/ADHD/Dyslexic person, effective and clear communication is critically important to me. Being able to achieve that in a program is satisfying in the same way as fostering a healthy community.

qual strengths: I work best at a co-working space, because I have physical boundaries. There is nothing to fix, organize, clean or do outside of my chair when I am at my co-working space. I also do best pair programming but our company has very little culture around that. I am thinking of leaving this team to find a team to lead that wants to do pair and/or mob programming and also do Ultraworking (30m sprints, 10m breaks) with small bursts of HIT during the 10m break to achieve high bpm heart rate to release dopamine. We would all work together to code, document, and review everything. We'd work for 5 hours a day and be super focused and have the rest of the day off.

Mentoring of others,

Q3_12: I am neurotypical and do not have any of the above conditions
Q16: Work from home: I work from home the majority of the time
Q78: Hybrid: partially working out-of-office, and some in-office
qual strengths:
Role 1: Designing systems and following through from initial briefing to deployment, either implementing them myself or assigning predefined tasks to my team
Why: it's challenging and both customers and fellow IT departments (e.g. Operations and IT Security) are usually very satisfied with the systems I come up with
Role 2: DevOps - designing workflows for the team and developing tools to ease operation
Why: well planned workflows ensure we can better focus on development rather than troubleshooting and providing useful tools for us and the main operations team gives us a good standing with the operations team and helps getting our requests prioritized
strats_6: Recording meetings or taking notes during meetings
strats_7: Deliberately choosing a job that supports my work style or needs
strats_9: Changing my work or virtual environment to focus (e.g., using a simpler IDE, working from home, moving to a quieter space, etc.)
strats_11: Frequent communication with others to reduce confusion around tasks
strats_13: Breaking up a task into smaller steps
strats_15: Adding stimuli for focus (e.g., using stim objects, listening to music that gets me "in the zone," doodling, etc.)
strats_17: Following rituals or outlined procedures to complete tasks
Q88: Several Gitlab Project templates, Gitlab CI templates, Makefiles and written workflow definitions which formalize many regular tasks in my job and can be rigorously followed to achieve stable results and not forget important steps; also some smaller tools and Ansible playbooks to automate frequent tasks
Q23: The immediate working environment and especially management make all the difference. In my current environment everyone wants to cooperate and we grow as a team. Our boss asks what we need to reach company goals and helps us where possible rather than demanding results without consideration for external factors. I did well worse on previous teams where the work environment was less cooperative and more toxic.
Q24: Although we manage to keep a good balance between output velocity and maintainability there always seem to be less talented people available than required to satisfy all customer requests with a good quality result. Usually we have to either decline some low priority projects or lower our standards on some time critical projects which leads to more clean up work in the aftermath. I can't remember any time in the past 5 years where there was not something to work on in the backlog. Occasionally the backlog affects my well-being out of office hours, although that's rather my internal desire to not let customers down rather than external pressure from management.

Q3_12: I am neurotypical and do not have any of the above conditions
Q16: In person: I work in person the majority of the time
Q78: Hybrid: partially working out-of-office, and some in-office
qual strengths:
Teaching/mentoring new people on the project. I enjoy helping people feel competent and giving them the practical and emotional support to enable that. I'm also good at explaining difficult concepts in a way that is approachable.

Debugging issues/helping others figure out issues they're experiencing. I love figuring out why things aren't working, at least when I know the software stack well. If I'm unfamiliar with the domain and having to debug, it can be a bit overwhelming where to start (you have to figure out where the knowledge gaps are to then fill them and THEN actually begin starting to know where to investigate for the root of the issue).

Taking high-level ideas and fleshing them out to a practical implementation through researching relevant approaches/tooling/libraries. I think this part of the job is fun, lots of tinkering, theorizing, reading through blogs/lib docs/etc. to figure out how to do something new. Sometimes this can be overwhelming if it's really complex though. I have to take lots of breaks to avoid getting too bogged down in information overload from time-to-time. This lets me subconsciously process the info I think and lets me pick back up what I was doing fresh.

This feels so comfortable I'm not sure I'd be wanting to switch jobs.
Q24: Working with other neuro-diverse people also have its fair share of challenges, but I think it's hard to completely separate it from people doing the same effort of understanding and accomodating towards me.

qual strengths:
I struggle maintaining larger or unorganised codebases because I struggle to find things and the task of 'understanding' the codebase is difficult for me to start. I usually have a lot of anxiety when working unless there's other people present in some form.

I work best from coffee shops with a moderate amount of background noise/activity closer to white noise, and ideally with one other person there to work as well. Sounds like the barista loudly calling out names where it distinctly rises above the background noise makes it more difficult to work.

At home I usually work with a twitch live stream on in the background for both background noise and approximation of other humans being present.

That results in pressure from both sides: rote at current work and urge to invent something sustainable (incl. financially).

Q16: Work from home: I work from home the majority of the time
Q59: VS Code (IDE), Terminal (Bash shell), Chrome Browser (dev tools)
Q78: Hybrid: partially working out-of-office, and some in-office
qual strengths:
I am better at maintaining complex systems, which typically involves debugging, reviewing changes, releasing patches, refactoring and preparing for future changes.

I think this work is underrecognized and undervalued: many people want to do something new or start/prototype something, then move on. Maintenance work is very challenging because diffs (red/green) and understanding the system behavior and implications of changes is a lot more challenging to work with than just a greenfield project. However, greenfield does require being OK making mistakes/being messy and just getting it out there, in addition to some creativity and design.

The problem is that it's hard to advocate for maintenance work at times, since many people don't inherently understand the value of keeping a money-making system well maintained, nor the difficulties of dealing with technical debt.

I think I excel in maintaining complex systems because I am able to grasp the system as a whole and weigh changes and processes against that knowledge base with relative ease. For these reasons, I've often found myself as the go-to release manager and code reviewer for big projects. I just hold more "working memory" of the system than most.

Q17: Extremely severe sleep apnea (CPAP is not optional), While I'm not currently suffering from Depression I've had chronic clinical depression for the most of the last 5 years
Q23: The startups that I've worked for have largely been dominated by technical males that sort of "speak over" one another. There is very little in terms of democracy and autonomy (despite software often having teams with autonomy over specific systems). This is not friendly towards ND people who struggle to navigate these kinds of social situations and hierarchies. I'd strongly prefer working with small teams having ownership over components, with little room for crossover. While gatekeeping isn't always great, it's just easier to maintain and keep track of changes and understand system-scope. I really dislike the ambiguity in startups - they can be chaotic free-for-alls, where the loudest voices and bulldozers win.
Q24: Remove micromanagement and god-awful standups, less meetings and meetings should not have video, meetings need clearer notes, and there should be more of a component/team architecture rather than a free-for-all. Teams should be more focused with their goals, meetings etc.

Q89_3: Proctored technical assessment (i.e., timed, while someone watches)
qual strengths: Tasks: Software architecture, development strategy, domain modeling, business development - the number of moving parts is fairly small at that level of abstraction, and the problem domain is close to real life, I find the implementation details tedious and boring, but love the crispness of formal systems. Environment: Mostly remote in pairs or triples, with monthly-or-so in-person meetings - I tend to procrastinate challenging tasks, and sharing concerns and thoughts with peers reliably unblocks me by forcing me to identify friction points to overcome first.

Q23: A significant amount of people in my community-of-practice are neurodivergent, and yet rarely anyone takes notes during meetings. My help with doing that is appreciated greatly.
Q24: The entire day should count as worked regardless of and when code was written. I spend a lot of time reading or ruminating or talking seemingly non-committal or off-topic or meta things, but they all contribute to the outcome, but that can rarely be billed or even made visible appropriately. This results in me working 60 hours per week and only billing 20.

Q16: Work from home: I work from home the majority of the time
qual strengths:
Solving really hard problems that others don't even want to touch. I think so because that's what my colleagues told me after I've solved problems that had not been solved before me and not due to a lack of attempts.

Writing very high-quality tests. I think so because I measure the quality of tests, have written my own tooling, read papers on how it's done properly etc. I've only seen a few people who can even comprehend what it means to write high-quality tests and what it takes to do so.

Turning mess into well-structured code. I think so because I've worked on the same project for six years and it's still not "legacy". It's easy for me to work with my own code, I don't get slowed down over time, it's the opposite: the more I work on something, the easier it is for me to evolve it.

Finding issues during code review. I think so because I regularly find issues during code reviews.

I excel at writing documentation, even though I hate it. I think so because my colleagues told me that.

Q88: My keybindings are so customized that it took me weeks to get used to that and my IDE is completely unusable to anybody except me. It's a mix of vim-style modal editing and emacs-style key prefixing. I also keep my fingers on the keyboard in a different way than others (right index finger on "k"). I've customized nearly every single object and color in my editor in order for them not to annoy me. I've implemented my own procedures for text navigation and editing, because the defaults were misbehaving.

qual strengths:
I enjoyed my previous job a lot more than my most recent one. I was working on embedded systems in the Defense industry. I had a lot more autonomy (in terms of the work I was doing) and had a much larger impact. The work was more challenging but less abstract. I spent much more time training/guiding junior engineers.

To give you an example, I designed and built a prototype that used GPS and radar to track drones, then demo'd it at a conference and it got on TV. In my most recent job, I often worked on software that barely anyone used.

I am also worried that accommodations would be incompatible with the relaxed/casual company culture.

Q4: I self-identify as having ADHD
Q16: Work from home: I work from home the majority of the time
Q89_7: Unproctored technical assessment (i.e., timed, with no one watching)
qual strengths:
My brain excels with tasks requiring logic, analysis and attention to many interconnected details - the more challenging the task the better. Ideal role would be some kind of R&D position; or (my current position) a guy who maintains the core of a system where most of the business logic (and thus complexity) lies.

Ideal work environment would be some secluded place, with little to no external interruptions (via messengers, email or phone). Because it's really hard for me to get back on track even after the most minor outside interruption.

Why do I think so? That a result of introspection and self-analysis, especially after retrospectively assessing my life experiences in context that I was living with a combination of Aperger's and ADHD (and didn't even realize it was the case, until 35; now I'm 36).

Q23: I have a wife and kids with ADHD. I suspect there are probably several neurodivergent people in my workplace, but none of them that I know for sure. I believe that a lot of developers who are neurodivergent may be capable of working very productively, but that they will benefit from accomodations and accessibility adaptations. I believe management would benefit from increased knowledge and understanding of these topics, because I think it is quite important e.g. for people with ADHD to be put in positions, roles, and environments that have different requirements than for neurotypical people.

Q23: I have worked at a lot of different companies and accessibility has varied greatly.  One thing that hasn't varied is that many, usually the majority, of programmers are neurodivergent.  Rarely are their needs accommodated except by the rare gifted, empathetic manager.
Q24: I do a lot of things to minimize distraction in my development environment, such as only allowing fullscreen windows with no notifications or decorations, and removing all visual clutter from my editor.  However, most modern workplaces require the use of tools like Slack where these changes can't be done and the pressure to be constantly reactive is high.  (Slack used to have an IRC gateway that allowed using stripped down clients and filtering, but they shut it down ages ago.)

Having a green field for creative thinking, fast iteration, not having to deal with tech-debt, applying experience from previous iterations gets me in the flow the most (hyperfocusing the whole day sometimes...). But it results in a lot of unfinished projects...

Q4: I am professionally diagnosed with ADHD
country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
Q16: Hybrid: I work from home some days out of the week, and in person others
Q78: Hybrid: partially working out-of-office, and some in-office
qual strengths: I excel at cleaning up code and spotting dangling, unused or unoptimised code in my colleagues' work. I know this is only a personal perception but sometimes I feel like my propensity to do that is a bit obsessive. My colleagues appreciate what I do with the codebase but I deliberately try not to overdo it so that I'm not seen as a stickler for code quality. I do pay attention to the Lint hints in the IDE and I'm often surprised others don't. I don't comment on it though, I just suggest the changes in code reviews. I am not particularly quick at grasping new concepts or solving problems at scale, but that's probably due to my ADD. I'm always impressed how my colleagues are able to see things form bird's eye view. I excel at the nitty gritty at code level only. Hence I always feel like I'm behind in system design. This is probably also I always failed interviews which include data structures and algorithms becuase they require quick fire answers and the ability to think about abstract things at short period of time. I see myself as a principled developer but within a niche. I interviewed once at Google and Facebook and failed spectacularly. I've never been invited back. It hurt, but I hadn't told them about my neurodiversity as I have always kept it close to my chest since the diagnosis in 2013. I digress! I enjoy routine tasks like writing unit tests and that's also something I spot in my colleagues' work , if they are missing. If I spot existing classes untested as part of my work I add tests to them too, for completeness. This is something my colleagues appreciate in my work too.
strats_6: Recording meetings or taking notes during meetings
strats_7: Deliberately choosing a job that supports my work style or needs
strats_11: Frequent communication with others to reduce confusion around tasks
strats_13: Breaking up a task into smaller steps

strats_17: Following rituals or outlined procedures to complete tasks
reason for employer _7_TEXT: I didn't want to, but I was late for a stand up after doing my prescription run. The boss wasn't a sympatetic one and he pushed me for an answer. I told him about my recent diagnosis and the truth. Very hurtfully, he then reported my diagnosis to HR copying me in, basically letting out my secret for no other reason than retaliation. I haven't shared my diagnosis with anyone at work since.
neg outcomes _3: Employer told others you were neurodivergent without your consent
neg outcomes _6_TEXT: He reported my diagnosis to HR without asking me if I wanted that. I felt hurt and betrayed. I didn't share my diagnosis with anyone at work since (2013).
acc possible: Yes, I know it is possible
acc want _11: I have never asked for nor wanted accommodations at my job
acc grant _1: I have never received accommodations at my job
Q23: We've come a long way since my diagnosis in 2013 with regards to acceptance and discussions about neurodiversity at workplace and society as a whole. Back then I chose to keep it close to my chest in order to avoid being stigmatised by it, especially as I used to go to meetups a lot and I'd hate if everyone in the local industry found out and potentially locked me out of a job in the future. I was diagnosed at 31 yo but since 19yo I had developed lots of coping mechanisms for my "faults" and weaknesses so I'd already learned how to hide some things. If there is one negative thing in the recent years of talking about ADD/ADHD is that it seemingly became almost hip and cool to be neurodiverse and there are lost of fake diagnoses which people get and then are prescribed the drugs forever leading to frequent shortages. I genuinely need my drugs. When I don't take them my work and family life suffer. I wish people were being properly diagnosed and regularly re-diagnosed for the benefit of all. not sure if that's what this question was about now! ok is software dev good for neurodiversity - 100% it is, but there is a limit to our abilities. I don't see myself managing people and I worry that my inability to think at system design level will hold me at senior level forever and one day I might become less desireable at my job. I suppose I do worry about future job security. then I might come out.
Q24: renumeration increases not based on higher titles - as I say , I worry that my ADD has created a glass ceiling. I could never go above a Lead Dev. I dont see myself managing people nor getting to Director level. My neurodiverse brain couldn't deal with it.

qual strengths:
I prefer optimisation tasks, i.e. something with a very small scope, but a lot of finesse.

I prefer calm, peaceful environments, where I can focus on the problem under study undisturbed. (I always have some video game background music on, preferably ambient but almost always in over-ear headphones for obvious practical reasons.)
Nonetheless, I vastly prefer more open-plan offices to cubicles or other individual rooms, simply so it feels more organic and less isolated.

I think I prefer expert programming tasks; I do not think I enjoy coordinating people much, though I am considering exploring that field.

Q89_8_TEXT: Aptitude (online)
qual strengths:
Excel/High Satisfaction at code revision to simplify and enhance code maintenence  
Excel/High Satisfaction at finding root cause for issues
Excel/Enjoy developing solutions to complex problems that at supposed to be impossible
These tasks take attention to detail, creativity, and the ability to identify/create patterns, which my brain all the time. I often spot areas that can use the same function call, but others miss due to the naming conventions. In root casue analysis, I tend to visualize deep code as logical gates, which allows me to see where a logical error has occured. (I am SSMBB certified and earned the certification after reading a single book, on the job experience, and passing a single test.)

Q89_7: Unproctored technical assessment (i.e., timed, with no one watching)
qual strengths: Remote environments definitely. Working around other people is very distracting. Pair programming is completely unproductive. I can't concentrate on the task while also communicating with someone else about it. I think the only time I could do that is if I've done it 100 times before and it's trivial. If I have to actually think about it then I need the freedom to try things, fail, research other ways, build prototypes, etc. Not the kind of things that needs an audience and having someone watch while I think through things is distracting and intimidating

Q23: I think most employers (mine at least) claim to be understanding of neurodivergent people. However individuals in the organization don't necessarily agree with that. I've seen discrimination in how people are treated and talked about behind their back, and I've seen someone fired because a manager didn't know how to work with them. They were throwing random tasks at the guy with no concrete goals and changing the criteria constantly and wondered why he couldn't get it complete when they kept changing the definition of what would complete it.
Q24: I wish more managers had training about how incredibly productive neurodivergant people can be if you just know how to work with them. Yelling at them while heaping more tasks on them makes the problems worse. Giving managable tasks with clear goals though can be beneficial to everyone, regardless of whether they are neurodivergent.

qual strengths:
* feature development in software spaces that I am knowledgeable in, such as front end engineering. I have become comfortable with the development paradigms and fast at working within them.
* Anything that involves visual debugging (i.e., can figure out what is wrong with front end code just by looking at the user interface), I'm a "visual learner", good with recognizing patterns and seeing inconsistencies.
* Also quite good at starting from zero and iteratively building up/improving new software (could be data analysis, ML, user interfaces, any application, as long as I built it from the ground up and therefore have a thorough understanding of the application/system). I think I have a lot of experience with the iterative prototyping/development cycle from my engineering education, so it is fun and comfortable for me.

Q89_7: Unproctored technical assessment (i.e., timed, with no one watching)
qual strengths: I excel at (and enjoy) finding simple, composable solutions to complex problems and automating day today workflows for myself and my colleagues. I frequently find that I am able to identify approaches to solving problems that cut out a lot of complexity that existing solutions take for granted, while at the same time finding it challenging to work with systems not written in this way. I suspect that this approach is because I need to be able to break problems down into these simple composable parts to be able to think about them.

qual strengths:
I love debugging complex issues - having to go through multiple layers of software and/or hardware can be both extremely frustrating and extremely rewarding (e.g. finding out memory leaks or unexpected crashes).

I think I like it, because I can quickly grasp what each part of software (a single function, a single binary etc.) is supposed to do and I'm quick to filter out noise (e.g. functions that are obviously correct and couldn't have caused the bug), mostly by following my hunches and keeping a lot of context in the head.
